forecast.no_outcome_scenario: May 2025 would not be the hottest May if cooling from the El Niño to La Niña transition is stronger than expected, or if May 2024 (or another recent May) set such an exceptionally high bar that natural monthly variability keeps May 2025 from surpassing it. forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: May 2025 becomes the hottest May if the long-term warming trend continues to dominate over any cooling from the ENSO transition, or if atmospheric and oceanic circulation patterns in May 2025 happen to align favorably with warm anomalies in key regions that drive the global average.
forecast.rationale: This forecast balances several competing factors. On one hand, the 2023-2024 period has seen extraordinary global warmth with numerous monthly records falling, suggesting momentum toward continued records. The underlying climate change trend continues to push baseline temperatures higher each decade. On the other hand, we're currently transitioning from El Niño (warming influence) toward neutral or La Niña conditions, which could moderate temperatures. Additionally, after an extended period of record-breaking months, some statistical regression toward the mean becomes more likely - May 2024 likely set a very high bar. Without specific preliminary data from my research assistant about May 2025 temperatures or how May 2024 ranked historically, I must weigh these factors with appropriate uncertainty. The forecast would increase if preliminary data showed May 2025 running exceptionally warm, or if May 2024 was only marginally the previous record. It would decrease if May 2024 was an extreme outlier or if early signals suggest May 2025 was relatively cool. The 40% probability reflects that while conditions favor warmth, beating the specific previous May record requires the confluence of trend and favorable variability.
